descript.abstract: This feature class contains sidewalks, crosswalks, and other public or semi-public pedestrian pathways and connections within the City of Asheville (COA) Corporate Limits.
descript.purpose: Developed for purposes of reporting, CIP planning and navigation.

idinfo.accconst: This data has been developed using public funds. The data is therefore in the public domain. Requestors agree that they will not sell this data, will not sell access to the data, nor will they provide for such to be sold except as allowed in NC General Statutes Chapter 132. As a condition of providing electronic GIS data, the City of Asheville reserves the right to require that the data requester agree in writing that the data will not be resold or otherwise used for trade or commercial purposes. The City of Asheville reserves the right to license clients to reproduce GIS data for royalty fees based on the resale of the data and or based on a reciprocal agreement of products, services, or data.
idinfo.useconst:
The City of Asheville acquires, develops, maintains and uses GIS data in support of its internal business functions and the public services it provides. The GIS data which the City of Asheville distributes and to which it provides access may not be suitable for other purposes or uses. It is the requestor's responsibility to verify any information derived from the GIS data before making any decisions or taking any actions based on the information.
The City of Asheville shall not be held liable for any errors in the GIS data. This includes errors of omission, commission, errors concerning the content of the data, and relative and positional accuracy of the data. Source information used for these data may have been collected at different scales, times or definitions, resulting in inconsistencies among features represented together on this map. Primary sources from which these data were compiled must be consulted for verification of information contained in the data. The City of Asheville will not re-distribute data developed from other organizations. Parcel data was prepared for the inventory of real property found within this jurisdiction, and is compiled from recorded deeds, plats, and other public records and data. Users of the data are hereby notified that the aforementioned public primary information sources should be consulted for verification of the information. The City of Asheville assumes no legal responsibility for this information. Data are presented using the North Carolina State Plane Coordinate System 1983 North American Datum. Horizontal measurement units are in feet.
idinfo.native: Microsoft Windows XP Version 5.1 (Build 2600) Service Pack 3; ESRI ArcCatalog 9.3.1.1850

attracc.attraccr: The attribute accuracy for the sidewalks is excellent based on a deductive estimate of the attribute entry process. Attributes for this data set are limited to the segment type and a material attribute that diffentiates use and construction material.

dataqual.logic: Logical consistency tested to ensure that all chains intersect at nodes.

horizpa.horizpar: No tests were done to verify horizontal accuracy. The horizontal accuracy of the sidewalks is limited by the horizontal accuracy of the source data sets, the lowest of which is 4800. Generally digitizing is held at 1:240 scale or greater to insure scale consistency.

srcinfo.srccontr: 2006 digital orthophotography was used to determine the proper location for sidewalk segments that travel through the COA. This process was done through on-screen digitizing in ArcMap 9.3.
Index2002_Clip was used to determine the boundary of the City of Asheville.
Sidewalk presence was used to help identify where existing sidewalks locations were known
Needed sidewalk segments identified "fee-in-lieu" areas in the COA.
Buncombe county property boundaries was used in identifiying city owned property including parks, schools, and sidewalks.
Google street view was used to help identify sidewalk segments that could not be seen in the 2006 digital orthophotography.

procstep.procdesc: Created line feature class by digitizing sidewalks as seen on the the 2006 digital orthophotography at a scale of 1:240 or greater within the COA. The line features are seperated into seven subtypes
Used Google street view to identify segments of sidewalk, which were either obstructed in the 2006 digital orthophotography or had been modified since the 2006 imagery was taken.
Checked arc-node topology by verifying that there are no dangling lines. Unintentional dangling lines were corrected.

altsys.altenc: Explicit elevation coordinate included with horizontal coordinates

attrdomv.udom: Sequential unique whole numbers that are automatically generated.

attr.attrdef: Miscellaneous comments related to sidewalk segments
Trigger field that lists user name of person who last edited a feature or feature attribute.
Trigger field that timestamps the last feature or feature attribute edit.
Provides a list of specific sidewalk types.

edom.edomvd: Sidewalks in the the City of Asheville
Attaches segments together where pedestrian crossing might occur, but is not represented by marked crosswalk.
Attaches segments together across a large open driveway.
Attaches segments together across a large open parking area.
Attaches segments together where pedestrian crossing might occur, but is neither represented by sidewalk, crosswalk, greenway, or parkway
Marked areas for pedestrian street crossing
Pedestrian walkway within the Housing Authority properties, UNCA, AB-Tech, or other private walkways that are used by the public and that connect public walkways.
Designated greenway in the City of Asheville
edom.edomvds: City of Asheville Parks, Recreation, and Cultural Arts

edom.edomvd: Propsed greenway segment in the City of Asheville
edom.edomvds: City of Asheville Parks, Recreation, & Cultural Arts

edom.edomvd: Potential sidewalk segment identified as a priority in the City of Asheville 2005 Pedestrian Plan. Needed linkages are used in planning pedestrian investment by the city and in the development process to identify streets on which developers are not offered the option of choosing to pay a fee in lieu of sidewalk rather than installing sidewalk with the project (reference city sidewalk ordinance).
Sidewalk and trail segments in City of Asheville parks
edom.edomvds: City of Asheville Parks, Recreation, and Cultural Arts

edom.edomvd: Pedestrian bridges in the City of Asheville that connect sidesalks across busy roadways.
Potential sidewalk segments identified through public comment in the City of Asehville 2005 Pedestrian Plan.
Sidewalk segments funded through the American Recovery and Reinvestment Act. As these segments are completed, they will be changed to "sidewalks".

attr.attrdef: Name of street adjacent to sidewalk

metainfo.metstdn: FGDC Content Standards for Digital Geospatial Metadata
